entry.title: One-Click Export-Automating SuccessFactors EC API Metadata to Excel
entry.content:
Hi Successfolks!

In this blog, I will introduce how to use an automated Python script to mass export the SuccessFactors Employee Central OData API Data Dictionary. This aims to reduce the manual workload for SuccessFactors integration consultants when organizing integration workbooks.

Why Mass Export OData API Dictionary Matter?

Introduction:

Master data integration is a complex and time-consuming process that typically involves requirement gathering, API identification, field mapping, development, testing, and deployment. Exporting the Employee Central OData API dictionary is particularly tedious—especially when field configurations change frequently during new implementations.

Background:

There are four known ways to export the SuccessFactors OData API dictionary, but none are ideal. Most require manual steps, are inefficient, and lack user-friendliness. Therefore, a solution that is automated, efficient, real-time, and reusable is needed to accelerate the dictionary extraction process. This allows consultants to focus on strategic tasks rather than repetitive work.


Solution
Advantage
Disadvantage
Use SuccessFactors OData API Metadata Endpoint DirectlyProvides real-time API metadata; developer-friendlyLacks documentation and hard to repurpose as a delivery artifact
Use OData API Dictionary in Admin CenterTable format and support to searchRequires manual copy-pasting to Excel page-by-page; not export-friendly
Use Data Model in Integration CenterExport the table and show the table relationship via pictureNot readable easily
Use Standard API Dictionary in SAP API Business HubOffers standardized dictionary and frameworkNot environment-specific; needs updates to match customer-specific configurations

Solution

Export selected entities into a clean, formatted Excel file using the SF Metadata OData API and a Python automation script.

Key benefits of automation:

  1. Automated and Streamlined Process: Significantly reduces manual effort in exporting the OData API dictionary.
  2. Lightweight and Reusable: Can be reused across instances by adjusting a few variables in the script.
  3. Real-time responsiveness: Enables mass updates to the API dictionary instantly with one click.

How to Get Started

Prerequisite

Python environment (Refer to online tutorials for setup on Windows or Mac)

SF instance API endpoint and credentials

Process

1. Download Python Script and Other Asset via Github

Download 'EC Odata API Dictionary Extract.py' and 'SF Employee Central API AttributeV2.xlsx' into local folder via https://github.com/Berg-Song/SuccessFactors_API_Metadata_Extraction/tree/main

2. Update the variable in the script and Run

Update the variable in the script based on your instance info.

  1. API_SERVER: The API Endpoint for your instance's data center server.
  2. ENTITY_SETS: Comma-separated list of entity names to query
  3. USERNAME: The username of basic authentication
  4. PASSWORD: The password of basic authentication.

Note: OAuth2.0 version is planned for future release.

Run the script

Use an IDE (e.g., Visual Studio Code) to execute the script. An output 'EC_APIField_Metadata.xlsx' will be generated in the same directory.

EC Entity Sheet: Contains metadata for all entities listed in ENTITY_SETS

Simple EC Data API Dictionary Sheet: List the most important field attribute for the API fields. It could be customized by modifying the parameter in "simple_cols" of the script. The data is sorted by Entity, Name, Key, required attribute in order. The explanation for every attribute please refer to https://help.sap.com/docs/successfactors-platform/sap-successfactors-api-reference-guide-odata-v2/odata-annotations-for-properties?locale=en-US

Final Thoughts: API Dictionary Automation Journey Starts Now

This is the initial version of the automation export tool and it may not yet be perfect. I welcome your feedback and suggestions for improvement. Future enhancements may include broader module support, improved documentation, and additional helper materials. I hope this tool helps you set up and accelerate your master data integration more efficiently.😊

entry.title: Data Archival Solution for SAP SuccessFactors HCM
entry.content:
Current Challenge

Customers require an efficient, secure, and easily accessible method to access   historical HR data without sacrificing its value for reporting, analytics,  regulatory requirements , Payroll Retros and other use cases. 

 

Customer Scenario:

The customer is implementing SAP SuccessFactors HCM but has been using SAP ERP HCM/Legacy HR systems for 20+ years. As part of SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation usually up to  one year history will be  migrated to SF as a leading practice but remaining 19 years data is required to be archived and provide easy access to the HR Business team to support different requirements. This is a very common use case we see in any SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation project but there is no packaged solution to archive and provide access to Historical data from SF. 

Tech Envo  Solution:

The SAP SuccessFactors HCM Data Archival Solution is a purpose-built SAP BTP Extension Solution built on SAP BDC and provides a seamless access extension designed to seamlessly offload, store, and manage historical HR data from various legacy HR systems. Leveraging SAP Business Technology Platform, this solution provides a robust, centralized, and secure SaaS application for long-term data retention. It serves as a single source of truth for historical HR records, enabling optimized live system performance, cost reduction, streamlined reporting, and ensuring strict compliance with data retention policies and audit trails. 

Benefits

  1. Applications can be accessed in three ways.
    • Application which is embedded in the SAP Build Work Zone.
    • Application which is embedded in the SAP SuccessFactors Portlet.
    • Accessible as a Standalone SAP Fiori Application deployed on SAP BTP or SAP Launchpad.
  2. Archive Administrators can securely log in and access historical data using a familiar interface that mirrors the SAP SuccessFactors UI.

 

 

 

 

 


     

3. Prebuilt use cases to support different requirements. Currently Supported use cases are Rehire Check, Position Change Report, Do not Hire List, Tenure Data, Time in Position and Compensation Report.

4. UI is same as SAP SuccessFactors and blends seamlessly.

5. Users can view historical employee information such as Demographics, Payroll, Performance, Benefits, Certifications, and more.

 7. All access and visibility are controlled by SAP SuccessFactors Role-Based Permissions (RBP).

8.  The solution supports external systems via REST APIs like Power BI, Snowflake, and Informatica for extended integration.

9. Real-time changes from SAP SuccessFactors are synced with Data Lake, creating a single source of truth for HR data.

10.The system is fully configurable, allowing customers to define their own fields, rules, reports, and user interface as per their business needs.

11.Data Archival Solution supports both desktop and mobile platforms, ensuring user accessibility across devices.

 

This Solution by Tech Envo is a powerful, secure, and user-friendly solution that supports organizations in managing historical HR data effectively, ensuring performance optimization, compliance, and actionable insights.

Architecture and Technical Stack:

 

 

The Solution is available as a standalone application in SAP Build Work Zone on SAP BTP. It is built using the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP) with Node.js for the backend and SAP Fiori Elements (UI5) for the frontend. A BTP destination is configured to securely connect with the customer’s SAP SuccessFactors instance.

 

Flow:

  • The user launches the Data archival application via SAP Build Work Zone.
  • The request is routed through the App Router, which loads the UI from the HTML5 App Repository.
  • The App Router authenticates the user by obtaining a token from SAP XSUAA (authorization service)
  • This token is forwarded to the backend CAP service via the configured SAP Destination.
  • The Destination service securely connects the backend to the SAP SuccessFactors OData APIs.
  • The background job in SAP BDC invokes the SuccessFactors APIs to retrieve and archive employee data. 
  • Archived data is then pushed to storage targets like SAP HANA DB, SAP Data Sphere/Data Bricks (SAP BDC), or external Data Hubs (e.g., Snowflake, Kafka), depending on customer setup.

entry.title: One-Click Export-Automating SuccessFactors EC Standard New Hire Integration API Document
entry.content:
Hi Successfolks!

In this blog, I will introduce how to utilize an standard and reusable Python script to form the SuccessFactors Employee Central New Hire Integration API document based on SF metadata and API response extraction. This aims to streamline EC API document output and maximum the efficiency.

Why Auto-form SF EC API Integration Document Matter?

Background:

As an Integration Consultant, I regularly develop customized API documentation for customer-specific SuccessFactors integration scenarios, which I provide to downstream systems as technical reference. One of the most frequent and complex integration requirements involves new hire data synchronization - particularly when customers employ third-party recruiting solutions that must integrate with SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding (ONB) or Employee Central (EC). While the core HRIS element structure remains largely consistent across implementations, I currently spend significant time manually generating these new hire integration documents for each customer. Recognizing this as a repeatable process with predictable patterns, I plan to implement an automated solution to generate draft documentation. The automation will leverage standardized templates while accommodating necessary variations in customer-specific requirements, ultimately improving both efficiency and documentation quality.

Introduction:

With the power of SF OData API and Python, it is achievable to utilize through the following key steps:

  1. Extract SF EC master data metadata as mentioned in the blog: One-Click Export-Automating SuccessFactors EC API Metadata to Excel 
  2. Extract SF EC master data API Response.
  3. Re-organize the API response and API data dictionary.
  4. Mass upsert the re-structured API body based on specific rule and Capture Response.
  5. Fine Tune for the draft API document.

Document Template

Key benefits of automation:

  • Automated and Streamlined Process
    Significantly reduces manual effort in exporting the OData API dictionary.
  • Lightweight and Reusable
    Can be reused across instances by adjusting variables in the script if no customization is needed.
  • Real-time responsiveness
    Enables mass updates to API document instantly with one click once there exist new entity or field integration.

Key Concepts Behind the Solution

  1. Almost same standard EC HRIS Master Data Structure are enabled for different customer
  2. Body in Post API almost is the same with the API response in Get API after conversion
  3. upsertable attribute in Entity identify all fields which could appear in Body of post API.

How to Get Started

  2. SF instance API endpoint and credentials.
  3. A sample use case with full employee profile data.
    Please get necessary script via github: https://github.com/Berg-Song/SuccessFactors_API_Metadata_Extraction/tree/main

Extract SF EC Master Data Metadata

Run the first and second script to get the metadata for EC entity and fields and remove the unimportant column.
Please follow the blog to complete the task: One-Click Export-Automating SuccessFactors EC API Metadata to Excel

Extract SF EC Master Data API Response

Run the third script to get the API Response of all entities for one employee(https://{API_SERVER}/odata/v2/{entity}?&format=json&̲filter={filter_field} eq '{EmployeeId}) and remove the unnecessary key for upsert. Below show some important logic:

Different API query endpoint and key for different entity.

  1. userId for entity is started with "Emp" and "Background".

Remove the key-value in Body which is not upsertable.

  1. The key is started with created or lastModified, or contain "Nav" keyword.(Exclude Navigation field)

  1. Combine the sample value and field attribute.
  2. Remove the non-upsertable field from sample upsert body and data dictionary.
  3. Replace the value in boday with testing data, such as employee Id, position, hire date and so on as needed.

Re-Structure API Response and API data Dictionary

Mass Upsert the Re-structured API body And Capture Response

  1. Post API with valid upsertable body and capture response.
  2. Form the overall entity table and upsert API field attribute.
  3. Auto-populated the sample post API using the built-in API template.

entry.title: Simplifying Onboarding ADC with Internal Flags and Lookup Tables in SuccessFactors
entry.content:
Introduction

 

In complex, multi-country onboarding programs, the data we need to collect from new hires often depends on internal business logic. For instance, a role might be eligible for night shifts, require transport support, or fall under a high-risk location — but these decisions aren’t something we want candidates or hiring managers to manually provide.

Instead of storing these as standard fields, we approached them as derived logic — values inferred from known details like the candidate’s country or department or division and used only to shape the onboarding experience behind the scenes.

To avoid clutter and keep the configuration clean, we introduced virtual decision flags that are evaluated at runtime through a lookup table. These flags help us assign the right Additional Data Collection (ADC) UI, so each candidate sees only the fields that are relevant to their specific onboarding context.

What We Wanted to Solve:

We needed a setup that would:

  • Show or hide ADC fields based on internal business conditions
  • Avoid introducing new user-entered fields
  • Keep the candidate experience simple and relevant
  • Scale easily across countries without rewriting rules every time

 

Scenario Example: Global Onboarding Field Variations

Let’s consider a multinational organization onboarding employees across regions like India, Germany, UAE, etc.

The Logic Behind the UI

To make this work, we defined four internal logic flags:

  • Eligible for Night Shift
  • Requires Company Transport
  • Work Location Type (Office / Remote / Field)
  • Employment Zone (Metro / Non-Metro / High-Risk Area)

These flags are resolved dynamically based on EC values (like country) via a lookup table.

How We Designed It

  • The rule then resolves the flag combination at runtime and assigns the right UI variant.
  • Each UI is preconfigured with only the fields needed for that specific onboarding scenario.

This way, the entire logic layer sits quietly in the background — while candidates only see what truly applies to them.

By using standard SuccessFactors tools — lookup tables, business rules, and Configuration UI — we kept things clean, flexible, and scalable.

It’s a great example of how thoughtful logic design can quietly power a much better experience for both the business and the new hire.

entry.title: Discover the Updated Data Model Guide
entry.content:
Navigating data models in SAP SuccessFactors can be complex, but we’re making it easier, together. We’re excited to introduce the updated Data Model Guide, now featured in the Getting Started section of the Employee Central Help Portal page. This update is designed to help you and your teams quickly access the foundational information needed to configure and manage your SuccessFactors environment. Whether you're new to data models or refining an existing setup, this guide serves as a collaborative resource to align your efforts, reduce complexity, and accelerate implementation.

The updated data model guide is available on both the Employee Central and Platform pages. We recognized that users often had to consult multiple sources to understand field behaviors, localization requirements, and configuration dependencies. To address this, we enhanced the guide, ensuring easier findability and accessibility to the information you need. Each section that was added to the guide plays a vital role in helping users configure and manage their SAP SuccessFactors environments more effectively.

Please note that you must be logged in to the SAP Help Portal to access the data model content. It is not publicly available.  It is only accessible to SAP customers and partners. 

For more information, refer to the Setting Up Data Models and Managing Business Configuration guide. 

 

Data Models

Understand the different types of data models available and how they can be utilized effectively.

What’s Changed and Why:

We’ve restructured the guide to make it easier to understand the different types of data models in SAP SuccessFactors—Corporate, Succession, and Country/Region-Specific. This new layout offers a more intuitive and holistic view of how these models work together to shape your system’s structure.

These data models are the foundation for configuring Employee Central and other modules. They define everything from job structures to employee records. By including this section in the guide, we’re helping users see how each model contributes to the overall behavior of the system. This clarity leads to more accurate and efficient configurations, fewer errors, and a smoother implementation experience.

 

Foundation Objects

Learn about the essential building blocks that support your data structure.

What’s Changed and Why:

We’ve added Foundation Objects in the Data Model Guide. These are the core elements; like departments, locations, and job classifications, that define your organizational structure in SAP SuccessFactors.

The updated guide makes it easier to understand and configure. It gives you a clearer, more connected view of how the system is structured. Understanding this section helps you to dive deeper into how these objects function, how they relate to one another, and how they can be adapted for different countries and business units.

 

Business Configuration UI

Get acquainted with the user interface that facilitates seamless configuration management.

What’s Changed and Why:

We’ve added the Business Configuration UI (BCUI) guide to the Data Model Guide. This intuitive interface allows administrators to manage configuration settings directly, without needing to work with XML files. It’s designed to simplify the process and make configuration more accessible to a wider range of users.

Including BCUI in the Data Model Guide reflects our commitment to making configuration easier and faster. It empowers not just technical teams, but also HR professionals and business users who may not have a technical background. By placing BCUI within the broader data model context, users can better understand how their configuration choices impact the system’s structure and behavior, leading to more accurate and efficient setups.

 

Field Information

Access links to detailed field information specific to Employee Central fields, as well as the Country/Region-Specifics guide.

What’s Changed and Why:

This section links to detailed documentation on Employee Central fields as well as Country/Region-Specific configurations. It’s an essential reference for implementers who need to understand field behavior, dependencies, and localization requirements.

By embedding this information directly in the guide, it eliminates the need for external lookups, streamlines the configuration process, enhances usability, and supports faster, more consistent decision-making—ensuring that localization and configuration nuances are easily accessible.

 

Share Your Feedback


We value your input! As you explore the updated Data Model guide, you'll notice a link to a short survey. We’d be incredibly grateful if you could take a few minutes to share your thoughts with us. Your feedback plays a vital role in helping us continuously improve and tailor our resources to better support your needs.

entry.title: Celebrate Your Team: Setting Up Work Anniversary Alerts in SAP SuccessFactors, Made Easy!
entry.content:
Making your employees feel appreciated is a big part of creating a great workplace. One simple yet powerful way to do this is by recognizing their work anniversaries – celebrating how long they've been a valuable part of your team. While manually tracking and remembering these dates can be an administrative burden, SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central offers robust capabilities to automate this process.

This guide will provide a detailed, step-by-step approach to configuring automatic "work anniversary alerts" within SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central. We will explore how to leverage standard functionalities to create efficient and automated notifications, ensuring no employee milestone goes unnoticed. This proactive recognition strategy significantly enhances overall employee engagement and retention.

Let's make celebrating the teams easy and automatic!

Step 1: Provisioning Switches

Before we start building, we need to make sure your SAP SuccessFactors system has the right switches turned on in the background. 

Validate settings below are enabled in Provisioning (Company Settings):

  • SAP Best Practices Upgrades in Upgrade Center
  • Employee Central V2 features: Generic Objects, Effective Dated Data Platform, Employee Profile Data Audit, Attachment Manager
  • Employee Central Foundation Objects

Step 2 - Assign Permissions

To successfully implement and manage these configurations, ensure your user ID is granted the appropriate role-based permissions. We will need permissions to:

  • Manage Upgrade Center, Provisioning, Foundation Objects, and Business Configuration.
  • Import/Export data, manage Workflows, manage Picklists, and manage User Roles.
  • Specifically, confirm permissions for "Off-Cycle Event Batch" and "EC Alerts and Notifications" management.

Step 3 - Activate Best Practices Content

  • Navigate to Admin Center → Upgrade Center.
  • Filter by SAP Best Practices, find “Employee Central Anniversary Alerts”
  • Click Learn More & Upgrade Now, confirm, and track background job execution.

 

Step 4 - Monitor Activation Status

After triggering the upgrade, it's crucial to monitor its completion.

  • Monitor background jobs triggered by the activation.
  • Look out for the email titled “Best Practice Configurations Employee Central Anniversary Alerts COMPLETED” with detailed status logs.

 

Step 5 - System Configuration

This step involves configuring a custom field to store anniversary data and setting up critical background jobs.

Custom Field Setup:

  • Enable/validate custom field in Business Configuration
    Go to Manage Business Configuration → employmentInfo → add custom-long10 (Number of Years) → Save
  • Set role-based permissions for the new field (custom-long10) to the relevant admin roles

Scheduling Background Jobs:

Access Provisioning (or Manage Scheduled Jobs in Admin Center):

  • Create an Off‑Cycle Event Batch Processing Job set to run daily
  • Create EC Alerts and Notification Job, also daily, after the above job

It's vital to maintain this exact sequence. The BizX Off-Cycle Event Processing job must always complete before the EC Alerts & Notification job begins. If automating these daily, ensure this order is strictly preserved.

Job Owner Permissions: The job owner for these scheduled jobs must have edit access to write to the "Number of Years" field (custom-long10).

Step 6: Validating Off-Cycle Event Batch Configuration

The activation process creates a core object for handling anniversary calculations.

  • Navigate to Manage Data.
  • Locate the object Off Cycle Event Batch - SFCC_SERVICE_ANNIVERSARY.
  • Validate the information and update it as needed.
  • Confirm that the Associated Rule for calculating the "Number of Years" is correctly linked, update if required.
  • Ensure "Employment Details" is set as the Base Object within the Off Cycle Event Batch configuration.

 

  • Validate the Associated Rule to calculate the number of years under Manage Data - Off Cycle Event Batch -  Numberofyears. Use Employment Details as the Base Object in the Off-Cycle Event Batch Configuration.

 

Optional: Creating an Off-Cycle Event Batch User Group
You can create an Off Cycle Event Batch User Group and assign it under Manage Data - Off Cycle Event Batch.

Benefit: This group allows you to specify a subset of employees for batch processing, rather than processing the entire workforce if no filters are set. If no user group is assigned, the system will process every active employee record matching your batch filters (or all active employees if no filters are applied).

  • Create an Off Cycle Event Batch User Group and assign it under Manage Data - Off Cycle Event Batch. This is optional.

Step 7 - Set Up EC Alerts and Notifications

Create an alert workflow that specifies the recipient of the anniversary message (typically the employee , but can also include their manager, HR, etc.). This workflow will be assigned within the business rule.

Create Alert Messages for various anniversary years (e.g., 1-year, 5-year, 10-year). These messages will be sent to the employee. Ensure your messages are personalized and reflect your organization's recognition culture.

 

Create a business rule to trigger the work/service anniversary alert message based on the calculated "Number of Years."

Assign this business rule under Manage Business Configuration → employmentInfo → Trigger Rules.

Save your configurations.

By following these steps, you can establish a streamlined, automated system that recognizes and celebrates employee milestones, significantly enhancing engagement and retention. Leveraging SAP Best Practices ensures scalability across all employee populations and country localizations.

 

Error Handling & Re‑activation | Essential KBA References

  1. Verify Hire/Service Date sync.
    Ensure that the Hire Date (or Service Date) in Employee Central (EC) correctly syncs to the standard BizX Anniversary Date field. Misalignment here often causes anniversary alerts to fire on the wrong date— see 3171033 for details and resolution by performing a full HRIS export/import or sync.
  2. Validate the timing of the job, please ensure both the server date and today() should be the same date. It depends on your Data Center of your instance. 
  3. Handle Rehires & Service‑Date Calculation
    If employees are rehired, ensure your service anniversary logic accounts for breaks in employment and cumulative service time. Refer to KBA for guidance on calculating continuous service 2431354
  4. Resolve Off‑Cycle Event Batch issues.
    If active employees aren’t picked up by the Off‑Cycle Event Batch job (e.g., code SFCC_SERVICE_ANNIVERSARY), check your base object and filter settings. This is covered in 2945528 
  5. Troubleshoot job execution failures
    For scenarios where the Off‑Cycle Event Batch or EC Alerts & Notifications jobs run without generating alerts or emails, consult KBA  3519940, which covers workflow and email trigger failures (SAP login required.
  6. Ensure correct permissions and confirm the job owner and alert-triggering users have:
    Edit access to the "Number of Years" custom field (custom-long10), and Permissions to schedule, monitor, and execute Off‑Cycle Event Batch and EC Alerts jobs.

 

Conclusion

Setting up automatic work-anniversary alerts in Employee Central isn’t just a technical achievement—it's a meaningful way to weave consistent celebration and recognition into your organization’s culture. It signals to employees that their tenure and contributions are truly valued.

Please share your experiences, feedback, comments, or additional tips in the comments below. Let’s help each other make celebrating milestones both seamless and truly special! Thank you for reading this blog. Happy Learning!  🙂

entry.title: Understanding the impact of onboarding on the Assignment ID rule
entry.content:
In SuccessFactors Employee Central we have the Assignment ID field in Employment Info, by default this is populated during hire as the same value as the person id external.

If for example, we had a 9 digit code for person id external then the assignment ID would also be the same value.  If a third party systems needed an 8 digit code rather than 9 then you could utilise the employment setting configuration in Manage Data to create a rule as follows.  This rule gets triggered when you hire an employee and will set the Assignment ID to an 8 digit value.

In our example when we initiate onboarding the person id external is set with a 9 digit number and the assignment Id is also set as a 9 digit number.  The assignment rule is not triggered when you initiate onboarding, it is only triggered when the person is processed out of Manage Pending Hires.

Therefore, if we do not adjust the rule then the assignment ID will not be updated to an 8 digit number as the ‘if statement’ is looking for a ‘null’ value when it is actually already been set as a 9 digit code.

If you update the rule as follows this will set the Assignment ID to an 8 digit number.

Please note that until 2025H2 the assignment rule will not trigger for employees coming from onboarding as mentioned above, this is being fixed in the release.  In the meantime, if the rule is needed to be triggered please raise a support incident and SAP support can run a script to ensure the rule works as described.

entry.title: Employee Time Report as Individual Line Item - SAP SuccessFactors
entry.content:
Introduction:

This Report is all about a requirement from one from my clients where they wanted a Leave Report as an individual Line item rather than the aggregated form. It is also to be remembered that they do not own time tracking license and Story Reports are not enabled either.

How was the Requirement Achieved?

The Lack of Time Tracking License made things interesting and challenging. With time tracking license, Report fetched using Recorded time data v2 will deliver report with individual line items rather than the aggregated form. To better understand this, lets us take a case where an employee applies leave from Jan 01 - Jan 05, The Report fetched using Canva Reporting will deliver the output as Start Date Jan 01 and End Date Jan 05, which will not serve our purpose. The Expected result should be as follows:

 

Jan 01 Annual Leave
Jan 02 Annual Leave
Jan 03 Annual Leave
Jan 04 Annual Leave
Jan 05 Annual Leave

It was also confirmed by the Engineering Team of SAP, that this will not be feasible by Canva Reporting. So, I initially had a thought if this can be achieved using excel using VBA's which did not deliver output as expected. Then I started exploring open-source solutions and there I arrived at a solution using Python. Using Python, I input the file extracted from SAP SuccessFactors which would then split the records individually. However, the Headers mentioned in the Code should match with the Extracted Report from Sap SuccessFactors.

Python Code : 

import pandas as pd
from datetime import timedelta
from tkinter import Tk
from tkinter.filedialog import askopenfilename, asksaveasfilename
 
def split_leave_records():
    # Use tkinter to open a file dialog to select the input Excel file
    Tk().withdraw()  # Close the root Tk window
    file_path = askopenfilename(title="Select the Excel file containing aggregated leave records",
                                filetypes=[("Excel files", "*.xlsx *.xls")])
   
    if not file_path:
        print("No file selected.")
        return
 
    # Read the Excel file
    df = pd.read_excel(file_path)
 
    # Strip whitespace from column names and make them lowercase
    df.columns = df.columns.str.strip().str.lower()
 
    # Print the column names to check for the correct names
    print("Available columns in the file:", df.columns)
 
    # Dynamically check for the presence of expected columns
    required_columns = ['start date', 'end date', 'employee id', 'employee name',
                        'time type', 'approval status', 'quantity in days',
                        'department', 'position', 'application date', 'created by']
    missing_columns = [col for col in required_columns if col not in df.columns]
   
    if missing_columns:
        print(f"Error: Missing columns in the input file: {', '.join(missing_columns)}")
        return
 
    # Convert 'start date' and 'end date' to datetime
    df['start date'] = pd.to_datetime(df['start date'], errors='coerce')
    df['end date'] = pd.to_datetime(df['end date'], errors='coerce')
 
    # Check for invalid dates
    if df['start date'].isnull().any() or df['end date'].isnull().any():
        print("Error: Some 'start date' or 'end date' values could not be parsed.")
        return
 
    # Initialize a list to hold split records
    split_records = []
   
    # Iterate over each row to split the leave records
    for index, row in df.iterrows():
        employee_id = row['employee id']
        employee_name = row['employee name']
        start_date = row['start date']
        end_date = row['end date']
        time_type = row['time type']
        approval_status = row['approval status']
        quantity_in_days = row['quantity in days']
        department = row['department']  # This may be blank
        position_title = row['position']  # Renamed from position
        application_date = row['application date']
        created_by = row['created by']
 
        # Ensure start_date <= end_date
        if start_date > end_date:
            print(f"Error: Start date is after End date for Employee ID {employee_id}")
            continue
 
        # Generate individual records for each date in the range
        current_date = start_date
        day_count = 0
       
        while current_date <= end_date:
            split_records.append({
                'Application Date': application_date.date() if pd.notnull(application_date) else '',  # Keep only date part
                'Employee ID': employee_id,
                'Employee Name': employee_name,
                'Leave Date': current_date.date(),  # Keep only date part
                'Department': department,  # Leave blank if there's no data
                'Position Title': position_title,  # Renamed column
                'Time Type': time_type,
                'Quantity in Days': 1,      # Each split leave is considered 1 day
                'Approval Status': approval_status,
                'Created By': created_by
            })
            current_date += timedelta(days=1)
            day_count += 1
       
        # Warn if the number of days split doesn't match the quantity
        if day_count != quantity_in_days:
            print(f"Warning: Day count ({day_count}) doesn't match expected quantity ({quantity_in_days}) for Employee ID {employee_id}")
 
    # Create a DataFrame for the split records
    split_df = pd.DataFrame(split_records)
 
    # Reorder columns for the final output and remove 'Start Date' and 'End Date'
    split_df = split_df[[
        'Application Date', 'Employee ID', 'Employee Name', 'Leave Date',
        'Department', 'Position Title', 'Time Type',
        'Quantity in Days', 'Approval Status', 'Created By'
    ]]
 
    # Use tkinter to save the output Excel file
    output_file = asksaveasfilename(defaultextension=".xlsx",
                                    filetypes=[("Excel files", "*.xlsx *.xls")],
                                    title="Save the individual leave records to Excel file")
   
    if output_file:
        # Export the split records to a new Excel file
        split_df.to_excel(output_file, index=False)
        print(f"Individual leave records saved to {output_file}")
    else:
        print("Save operation cancelled.")
 
# Run the function to split leave records
split_leave_records()

entry.title: Maximizing Value with Position Management: What Every SAP SuccessFactors Customer Needs to Know
entry.content:
Position Management in SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central isn’t just a configuration decision - it’s the backbone of workforce planning, compliance, and talent strategy. Done right, it streamlines headcount planning, reduces admin burden, and ensures consistent data across Recruiting, Onboarding, and Succession. Done poorly, it creates a maze of manual approvals, rogue hiring, and inaccurate reporting.

This article distils best practices and common pitfalls from SAP’s recent Path to Success session delivered by Solution Experts Muge Das and Cristian Ocampo, helping you design Position Management to deliver measurable value; and not just features.

Why Position Management Matters

Think of a position as a “seat” in your organization. Whoever occupies it inherits job, org, and pay data; ensuring consistency across the employee lifecycle. But the value goes far beyond admin:

  • Workforce Planning & Compliance – Control headcount, budgets, and prevent “rogue hires.”
  • Faster Recruiting & Onboarding – Pre-filled requisitions save recruiter and manager time.
  • Succession & Talent – Plan successors and identify critical roles based on positions, not just people.
  • Cleaner Data, Less Effort – Automatic sync cuts manual updates and improves data integrity.

 

5 Essentials for Efficient Position Management

1. Governance First, Features Second

Before touching configuration, decide:

  • Who owns governance - central HR, HRBPs, or managers?
  • Who approves new positions - HR, Finanace, or both?
  • How often will you audit and clean inactive positions?

Best Practice: Let managers request positions, but keep approvals inside workflows—not buried in email threads.

2. Define Clear Creation vs Reuse Rules

Not every change needs a new position. Set simple rules:

  • Create new: new hires, major pay grade or role changes.
  • Reuse: vacant positions with no major changes.
  • Update existing: location or minor attribute changes.

Document and train HRBPs and managers upfront.

3. Make Managers Part of the Solution

Locking managers out of Position Management slows everyone down. The new Manage Team Positions quick actions (1H 2024) let managers:

  • View filled and vacant positions in their team.
  • Request new positions or update attributes—with guardrails via role-based permissions and workflows.

This shift frees HR to focus on strategy, not acting as the “help desk.”

4. Start Simple, Scale Smart

Myth: You need every feature activated to get value.

Reality: Start lean, then scale.

  • Begin with standard setup.
  • Add features like Matrix Positions, Mass Change Tools, or Right to Return (for leave/global assignments), only when needed.
  • Avoid over-engineering - too many custom fields prevent adoption.

5. Measure What Matters

Go-live isn’t success - impact is. Track:

  • HR Efficiency - Fewer manual updates, reduced ticket volume.
  • Manager Productivity - Less time lost on admin.
  • Data Quality - Fewer mismatches between position and employee records.

Use the Position Analysis Report Story and audit logs to show tangible value.

Common Pitfalls to Avoid

❌ Believing automation = no maintenance (you still need regular audits).

❌ Ignoring 3rd-party integrations (Right to Return can blank out position IDs!).

❌ Overcomplicating processes (too many approvals/custom fields slow adoption).

❌ Skipping training (managers & HRBPs need clear communication and guidance).

Ready to Take Position Management to the Next Level?

Position Management is a strategic enabler of better hiring, budget control, and talent planning - if governance, processes, and features work together and if managers and HR teams are confident using it.  If you haven’t already:

✅Map your governance and process rules - are best practices in place, or are workarounds costing you time?

✅Pilot "Manage Team Positions" with a small manager group - Pilot "EC Quick Actions", clean up your data, and test governance

✅Audit and clean up inactive positions before adding features.

✅Use SAP’s Best Practice Library (SAP SuccessFactors Process Library) and review Implementation Design Principles - updated design guidelines give you ready-made frameworks.

Don’t let Position Management sit idle as a “feature.” Make it the backbone of your workforce strategy - and start proving its value.

entry.title: Time Valuation to Allocate a Default of 8 Hours to TOIL for Saturdays, Regardless of Hours Worked
entry.content:
As a Time Management consultant, we come across many client requirements on a daily basis. Some of the requirements can be solved using standard solutions, while some need custom solutions. Recently, I got a requirement from client in Spain that they want to get a default 8Hours of time to TOIL Account ,  where if an employee works on Saturday which is either less than 8hours or more than 8hours , Default 8hours should be sent to TOIL account so later that employees can use that hours to take a comp-off leave as per the Spain legal regulations

Scenario: When employees work on Saturdays (Which is a non-working day as per work schedule), a default of 8 hours should be credited to their comp-off account, also known as the TOIL account, regardless of the actual hours worked on that day.

Steps to Achieve the Scenario:

To Achieve this scenario, In total I have configured a total of 3 valuations which are described below:

Valuation 1: Generate a fixed 8 hours within the specified time type group

 

Let's Decode Valuation 1:

This valuation is configured to get a fixed 8Hours into a time type group which will help us to carry those hours into Saturday Comp-off account on the recorded day .

Valuation Type: Create Time Record (This valuation is used to fetch the time specified within start and end time fields.) (Refer to screenshot 1 above)

Time Type Group Above: Default 8HRS serves as the above group, which is used to store the total hours of start and end time which means 8hours as per the mentioned timings. The category of the above group is taken as calculated time, which is used to store the total hours. (Refer to screenshot 2 above)

Valuation 2: Identifying the hours worked on Saturday (Either of any hour recorded on saturday)

 

 

Let's Decode Valuation 2:

This valuation is used to fetch hours worked on Saturday which is a non-working day in my case as per work schedule.

Valuation Type: Filter Input Groups (This valuation is used to filter input groups based on given time record criteria.) (Refer to screenshot 1 above)

Input Group: The Recorded Working Time group, used as working time, is assigned with my attendance types through which employee records time in timesheet (Refer to screenshot 2 above).

Time Records Filter: The Working Hours Saturday group is mainly used to specify Saturdays as non-working days according to my work schedule. I have specifically mentioned Saturdays and non-working days for greater precision. (Refer to screenshot 3 above)

Time Type Group Below: The Working Hours on Saturday group is used as the below group in above case, as the hours fetched by the filter group will always fall in this group. The time category of the below group is used as calculated time, which is mainly used to store the filtered hours. (Refer to screenshot 4 above)

Valuation 3: Compare Saturday Working hours, If more than 0 then route to above group regardless of hours recorded , which redirects the hours to TOIL Account


 

 

Let's Decode Valuation 3:

This valuation is designed to assess any time worked on Saturday and, if applicable, redirect the default 8 hours to the TOIL account. If no time is worked on Saturday, then no hours will be allocated to TOIL.

Valuation Type: Compare threshold with comparison group to route input (This valuation is used to compare the comparison group with a threshold and redirect the hours to either the above or below group.) (Refer to screenshot 1 above)

Input Group: The Default 8HRS group is the result group from first valuation mentioned above, which stores the default 8 hours. (Refer to Valuation 1)

Comparison Group: The Working Hours on Saturday group is taken from the second valuation above, which records hours worked on Saturdays. (Refer to Valuation 2)

Threshold Group: In this scenario, I want to send 8 hours to the TOIL account for anyone who works on Saturday, regardless of the actual hours worked. Therefore, I have set the threshold value to 0, meaning that if the hours exceed 0, the default input group will be sent to TOIL. (Refer to screenshot 1 above)

Time Type Group Above: The Saturday Default 8HRS into TOIL Group is used to store the hours and directly transfer them to the TOIL account, which employees can use to take time off. (Refer to screenshot 2 above)

Let's test this in timesheet:

Before Recording Time on Saturday

As you can see, before recording, there are no hours recorded on Saturday, and therefore, no hours have been sent to TOIL account which is also called as comp-off account.

After Recording Time on Saturday

In the screenshot above, you can see that I have recorded 1 hour on Saturday; then the default of 8 hours is sent to TOIL. In the TOIL tab, you can observe that 8 hours is added, while the summary shows the actual hours worked on Saturday as 1 hour, along with the default 8 hours sent to TOIL.

Hence, the same scenario can be used for Sunday's, Non-Working Days and Holiday's too

Thank you for reading! 😎
I hope this Blog provided valuable insights into unique Time Valuation. Feel free to share your thoughts, questions, or experiences in the comments below. Stay tuned for more SAP content!

entry.title: Leveraging SAP SuccessFactors Compensation for Salary Benchmarking
entry.content:
Though SAP has brought in several enhancements in compensation module, there isn't a direct solution to capture external salary benchmarking data and use it for comparison against existing pay ranges during annual compensation planning activity. However for one of my recent client who is into new-gen technology product development, wanted to have their top talents (some even hold individual patents to their names)  paid as per market.

Client does have subscription tie-up with an external vendor who provides market salary data which the management would like to leverage during their annual compensation planning exercise. After understanding their business nuances, I did try to auto update EC custom MDF through an integration but it did not materialize due to platform differences and firewall incidents. So, I resorted to import the data to SuccessFactors until technical handshake happens between two platforms. Let me share the solution here, so that the tech savvy HR's can think of incorporating.  

How SuccessFactors Compensation Supports Market Benchmarking
SuccessFactors does not provide market data, however supports in creating placeholder for utilizing market benchmarking data and comparing it with existing pay ranges in Employee Central

  • Importing Market Data: Market benchmark data can be obtained from vendors such as Mercer, Aon, etc. and imported into SuccessFactors. It can be either imported directly in Employee Central leveraging custom fields or can be imported in a specific lookup table in compensation module with Country and Pay Grade being the key fields against which 'Min', 'Mid' & 'Max' values are maintained.
  • Salary Pay Matrix: Direct EC Pay Matrix can be used in order to compare with market data for a specific pay grade of a specific country. This enables the planner to consider the market pay data while making compensation decision for the employee.

Technical briefing from SuccessFactors standpoint:

  • A placeholder will be created for the market data to be imported into SF system. Could be custom fields in EC or through compensation lookup tables (preferred for non-EC system)
  • Create a section on the worksheet which populates the min-mid-max of market pay for the pay grade/country which helps the planner to compare current pay versus market pay for the employee and make compensation recommendations accordingly 
  • If the prospective market data provider (external vendor) can connect SF system, using their end point URL we can build a custom integration where the data is extracted automatically though a scheduled job and stored in custom MDF in Employee Central.

Companies are always reinventing and so do our clients, hence organizations to remain competitive in the talent market always go the extra mile to persuade. We shall support them in implementing such cost effective solutions and realize true value of their SAP investments.

entry.title: Display of the Number of Goals per User in People Analytics Story Reporting
entry.content:
A typical requirement in talent management reporting is to show the number of employees according to the number of goals, i.e. performance goals or development goals. Such a chart could help to identify employees which have not yet defined any goals, or also employees which have too many or too less goals. In this blogpost alternative approaches are presented to realize such a reporting requirement in People Analytics Story Reporting.

Introduction

An important HR requirement in talent management is to identify employees which have not yet defined any goals, or also employees which have too many or too less goals. See left side in Figure 1 which shows

  • Total number of considered employees
  • Total number of Objective plans which is the number of combinations of employees and objective plans (e.g. if one employee has goals in 3 of the selected objective plans, then the number “3” is considered; if an employee has goals in a single objective plan or also in none of the selected objective plans, then the number “1” is considered)
  • Total number of Goals (e.g. if an employee has 3 goals in ‘objective plan A’ and 5 goals in ‘objective plan B’, then the number “8” is considered)
  • Number of Goals per Employee/Objective Plan, i.e. which is just the “Total number of Goals” divided by the “Total Number of  Objective Plans”

The chart in Figure 1 shows the “Total Number of Objective Plans“ according to the number of goals. You can see that there are 1229 employees which don’t have any goals in one of the selected objective plans, 28 employees with a single goal in the selected objective plans, 11 employees with 2 goals and so on.

 Figure 1   'Histogram' (more precise, 'chart of type "Bar/Column") to show the number of employees per number of goals

Solution Approach

In the following the different steps are explained how to create a query and the respective story to derive the chart as it is shown in Figure 1.

1. Query creation

Create the query as shown in Figure 2. Note that:

  • The object “Primary Objective Fields” from “All Templates” in schema “Objective Management” is used. This was chosen to allow the possibility to select one or multiple bonus plans as indicated in Figure 1 on the right.
  • The anchor of the query is “Basic User Information” from schema “User”. It is also possible to create the query the other way round. However, only when having "Basic User Information" as anchor it is possible to derive also the employees without any goal plans and goals.

Select at least fields like employee name, user ID, objective plan ID, objective plan name and goal. You might add also filters e.g. to consider only goal plans in status “completed”, “on track” but to ignore goal plans in status “Cancelled” or “Postponed”.

Figure 2   Query based on “All Templates” within schema “Objective Management”

2. Story measure calculations

Create the following 4 story calculations as indicated in Figure 3, 4, 5 and 6.

To illustrate the necessity to calculate the “Total Number of Objective Plans” let’s consider the following example: Assume there are 100 employees for “goal plan 2023” and 120 employees for “goal plan 2024”. Further assume you run the report for both bonus plans. Then the number of employees is 120 (under the assumption that the 100 employees of “goal plan 2023” are among the employees relevant for “goal plan 2024”). This is derived with the calculated measure “Employees” as shown in Figure 3. However, more important for our report is the combination of employees and goal plans which is 220 (=100 + 120). This is derived with the calculated measure “Total Number of Objective Plans” as shown in Figure 4.

Figure 3   Story calculation of type ‘Aggregation’ to derive the number of employees

Figure 4   Story calculation of type ‘Aggregation’ to derive the total number of objective plans

The next calculation is the overall number of “goals”. Let’s stick at the example from above; let’s assume that the 100 employees maintained in objective plan “goal plan 2023” overall 400 goals and that the 120 employees maintained in objective plan “goal plan 2024” overall 590 goals. Here, it could be possible that one goal as e.g. “Improve my leadership skills” is for some of the employees part of “goal plan 2023” as well as part of “goal plan 2024”. Nevertheless, the combination of employees and goal plans is 990 (=400 + 590). This is derived with the calculated measure “Total Number of Goals” as shown in Figure 5. To derive the “Number of Goals per Employee/Objective Plan” it is now just required to divide the “Total number of goals” and “Total Number of Objective Plans”. For the example here, this would be an average number of 4,5 goals (=990 / 220).

Figure 5   Story calculation of type ‘Aggregation’ to derive the number of goals

Figure 6   Story calculation of type ‘Calculated Measure’ to derive the quotient between “Number of Goals” and “Total Number  of Objective Plans”

 3. Story Dimension Calculation

The final calculation step is transforming the “Number of Goals per Employee/Objective Plan” into a dimension. It is important to consider the “Dimension Context”: Our use case is to show the Number of Goals per Employee and Objective Plan. Therefore, the dimension context is the employee (i.e. the field ‘User ID’) and the goal plan (i.e. ‘objective plan ID’). Here, the bit ‘tricky’ part is to find meaningful ‘goal ranges’ (i.e. ‘Member Name’) so that the visual representation results in a chart that basically resembles a Gaussian distribution (see Figure 7). Furthermore, it is recommended to provide a counter as prefix to the ’Member Name’ (i.e. (1), (2), (3), ….), so that the sorting works properly (if this ‘prefix would be missing, in the sample provided here the sorting would be “1 Goal”, “13-15 Goals”, “16 and More Goals”, “2 Goals”, “3 Goals”, ….).

Figure 7   Story calculation of type ‘Measure-Based Dimension’ to convert the “Number of Goals per Employee/Objective Plan”

4. Chart Creation

Finally, it is possible to create a visual presentation of the previously calculated figures. Figure 8 shows a “Bar/Column” chart with the measure “Total Number of Objective Plans” and dimension “Goal Ranges”.

Figure 8   Bar chart with measure ‘Total Number of Objective Plans’ and dimension ‘Goal Ranges’

5. Further remarks:

  • Of course, the presented approach works not only for goals/objective data but also for (1) any similar (e.g. performance form data) or (2) also slightly different use cases (e.g. number of particular benefits rolled out/claimed per employee).
  • Instead of manual definition of “Member Names” as shown in Figure 7 you could also tick “Use measure values as dimension members”. However, in addition to the shortcomings described above (1. no Gaussian distribution; 2. confusing sorting), ‘members’ without any ‘Goals per Employee/Objective Plan’ would not show up in the Bar Chart.
  • It is also possible to use a chart of type “Histogram”. Use “Total Number of Goals” as ‘Measure’ and “User ID” and "Objective Plan ID" as ‘Aggregation Dimension’. Then, you have to adjust the ‘Chart Properties’. It is not recommended to switch off ‘Automatically Set Range of Values’: With this option you would probably generate odd ranges. However, for the use case of goals it is recommended to use fixed ranges as e.g. “14” as “’Number of bins’ and “1” and “15” as ‘Minimum’/’Maximum’ (important: choose 'Number of Bins' plus "1" for the 'Maximum'; only then each range covers the range of "1.00"). As shown in Figure 9 this approach works also fine (compare numbers from Figure 1 with numbers of Figure 9). 
    Advantage: This approach is faster to implement; only "Total Number of Goals" (see Figure 5) needs to be created
    Disadvantage: (a) The case of employees without any goal (see 1st column of 1229 employees/goal plans without any goal defined) is missing and (b) Less flexibility regarding the definition of 'Goal Ranges' (in particular to define something like "More than 16 goals)"
    Therefore, the approach which is previously described is more recommended.

 Figure 9   Chart of type "Histogram" to show the number of goals per employee/objective plan

entry.title: Clean Core by Design: Using SAP Advanced Event Mesh (AEM) as the First Principle
entry.content:
In the digital era of today where digital transformation is every organization’s need, SAP Clean Core Principle is more than just a word, it's a among the foundational principle for enterprises looking to future-proof their SAP landscape. As per the SAP clean core approach, where technology is moving towards API first Approach, modular architectures, the organizations must decouple their custom logic instead of the application server to external API’s outside the application server layer to ensure agility, scalability, and reducing the upgrade complexity.

One of the most powerful enablers of this Clean Core approach is the event driven architecture through SAP Advanced Event Mesh (AEM), an enterprise-grade event brokering solution that supports real-time, event-driven architectures across hybrid landscapes.

In this blog, I’ll walk you through how to achieve Clean Core by adopting AEM as the first principle, laying the groundwork for a decoupled, scalable, and intelligent enterprise.

 The Clean Core Strategy — What and Why?

  1. Avoid Extensions where not required
  2. Upgrades should not interfere with the extensions and extensions should not interfere with the upgrades
  3. Decouple the extensions from the Standard
  4. Keep the custom code separate from the S4 Core

A Clean Code

The Clean Core strategy focuses on:

  • Keeping custom code, extensions, and integrations outside the SAP S/4HANA digital core.
  • Leveraging side-by-side extensibility using SAP BTP.
  • Using stable APIs and events to communicate between systems and layers.

This approach ensures that your core ERP remains clean, lean, and easily upgradeable—an essential factor for reducing TCO and accelerating innovation cycles.

In short, minimize extensions, decouple them from the standard, build side-by-side extensions on the BTP layer without touching the S4 HANA Core.

 Why AEM as the First Principle?

To achieve the clean core strategy, event driven architecture plays an important role by decoupling the processes through individual events, following the loosely couple framework and avoiding tightly coupled integrations.

SAP Advanced Event Mesh enables event-driven architecture (EDA) that decouples the source of truth (S/4HANA, SuccessFactors, C4C, etc.) from consumers (external apps, extensions, APIs). Here's why it's foundational to Clean Core:

  • Asynchronous Communication: No tight coupling between systems.
  • Loose Integration: Replace point-to-point interfaces with publish-subscribe models.
  • Extensibility: Let consumers build side-by-side extensions without modifying the core.
  • Scalability: Support multiple consumers with minimal configuration overhead.

 Clean Core in Action — Event-Driven Architecture with AEM

Let’s take a simple example: BP Onboarding in SAP S/4.

 Without Clean Core (Tightly Coupled):

  1. Custom ABAP enhancements in S/4HANA to trigger BP Creation/ Change Events.
  2. Direct API calls or IDoc triggers to downstream applications like ARIBA/ C4C/ Hybris/ External Applications from S/4.
  3. Every new consumer or change = new code or regression testing.

 With Clean Core (Using AEM):

  1. S/4 HANA triggers the BP Creation Event via Event Enablement Cockpit.
  2. AEM captures the events and routes it to all the subscribers.
  3. Subscribers (CPI, CAP apps, external systems) performs the required logic without modifying the core system.

No enhancement. No code in the core. Just events and clean extensions.

Common Use Cases Where AEM Drives Clean Core

  • Customer/Vendor Create in S/4HANA → Event to AEM → Update CRM/External apps.
  • Purchase Order Created → Event routed via AEM → Notify suppliers via external systems.
  • Material Master Update → Trigger downstream analytics apps or warehouse systems.

 Building Blocks of a Clean Core Event Strategy

1. Enable Eventing in Source System

    • Use Event Enablement Cockpit in S/4HANA (Cloud or Private Edition).

Within the SAP Application layer, where various types of event triggers are captured, these triggers can originate from the standard SAP mechanisms/ processes like Business Objects Repository(BOR) Event, Change Documents (CDHDR/ CDPOS), BTE(Business Transaction Event), IDOC Creation, Output Determination routines, and RAP based Event Triggers.

     

2. Route Event to AEM

    • Configure the required events in SAP S/4 to Publish Events to SAP Event Mesh/ AEM
    • Do the proper topic configurations and ensure secure connectivity.

3. Integrate with AEM

    • Use AMQP 1.0 protocol or SAP Event Mesh/ Advance Event Mesh Adapter in Integration Suite.

  1. Design Reusable Consumers
    • Keep business logic in SAP BTP (CAP, CPI, etc.).
    • Use topic naming standards (e.g., sap/s4/customer/created).

  2. Govern Events
    • Maintain versioning, documentation, and routing rules in AEM.


       

 Combine AEM with SAP Integration Suite or APIM

AEM becomes even more powerful when used alongside SAP Integration Suite:

  • Route events from AEM to CPI flows for orchestrations or APIM for Just Routing.
  • Use Process Integration for sync calls only where truly needed.

Summary

In SAP S/4 HANA, achieving Clean Core is no longer an optional choice, it’s a foundational strategy for designing scalable, maintainable, and future ready enterprise landscapes. This blogs explored how the SAP AEM empowers the organizations to adopt event driven architecture(EDA) that supports the Clean Core Principle by:

  • Decoupling the Core: Separating the custom logic, integrations, and extensions from the S/4HANA core using publish-subscribe event models.
  • Enabling Side-by-Side Extensibility: Leveraging SAP BTP and AEM to develop external applications and microservices without modifying the digital core.
  • Ensuring Upgrade Agility: Keeping the S/4 core untouched allows smooth upgrades with minimal regression testing.
  • Scaling Across Hybrid Landscapes: Distributing business events asynchronously to multiple consumers (on-premises and cloud) with minimal configuration overhead.

 Conclusion

Embracing SAP Advanced Event Mesh as the foundation of your integration and extension strategy ensures that you're not only building for the present, but also for the future. With AEM, you unlock a Clean Core architecture that is:

✅Upgradable
✅Extensible
✅Decoupled
✅Scalable

The Clean Core is no longer a destination, it’s a design principle. And AEM is your first step on that journey.

Recruitment to Onboarding to Manage Pending Hires to Employee Central

entry.title: A Failed Attempt at Implementing an Organization-Level HRBP Enhancement via Integration Center
entry.content:
Today, I’d like to share a solution attempt for enhancing organization-level HRBP management in SuccessFactors via Integration Center — and why it ultimately fell short. This idea originated from a customer requirement to manage HRBPs at the department level (similar to how department heads are managed), rather than at the individual or position level.

1. Requirement

Many customers prefer to manage HRBPs by department instead of person or position.
In this model:

  • HRBPs are maintained only in department data, not in job relationships.
  • Any HRBP update (due to termination, transfer, etc.) should automatically affect all employees under that department.

2. Typical Use Case

Example: In the Finance Department, HRBPs differ by region:

  • Finance – USA → HRBP A
  • Finance – Germany → HRBP B
  • Finance – China → HRBP C

An employee’s HRBP should be determined based on their department and location.

3. Background

Currently, standard SuccessFactors does not support HRBP management at the organization level.
Key points:

  • HRBP data can only be maintained in position relationships and job relationships, with synchronization between these two tables.
  • Maintaining HRBPs at the organization (department) level is unsupported, and cannot be automatically synced to employees’ job relationship data.

4. Custom Integration Enhancement Solution

Process Overview

The enhancement was designed with the following steps:

Step 1 – Create a Custom MDF Object
Create a departmentHR MDF object as a child of the Department general object.

Field Type Note
externalCodeStringAuto-generated — concatenates relationshipType and HRBP user ID
cust_HRUserHRBP User ID
cust_LocationGeneric ObjectLocation

Step 2 – Output Integration Center Job
Export employee job data (empJob) including:

  • userId
  • effectiveDate
  • sequence
  • location
  • Calculated column: HRBP (derived from location + division in job info)

 

Step 3 – Input Integration Center Job
Import and update job relationship records for each job info record, based on the exported data.

5. Limitation

This approach fails in scenarios where HRBP changes are future-dated but employees have no corresponding future-dated job info record.

Example:

Job Info:

UserId EffectiveDate HRBP
Employee-A2023-01-01A
Employee-A2024-01-02B

Department Data:

Department EffectiveDate HRBP
Dept-A2020-01-01A
Dept-A2024-01-01B
Dept-A2025-01-01C

Result: C will not appear for Employee-A until they have a job info record effective after 2025-01-01. This happens because:

  • empJob’s effective date is not derived from department effective dates.
  • Department data is fetched as of the job info’s effective date.
  • The future effective department record cannot be retrieved from empJob.

6. Thoughts for Improvement

  1. API-based Enhancement

    • Use API queries to:
      • Retrieve all employees under the department.
      • Retrieve all effective department records.
    • Insert corresponding HRBP records into job info for any date range between department effective dates.

  2. Using Standard “Manage Mass Change”

    • In standard SF, HRIS can use the Manage Mass Change tool to update HRBPs quickly whenever they change — even though this is manual, not automated.

7. Closing Thoughts

While this solution didn’t achieve the desired automation, I hope it provides some insight and sparks discussion. I’d greatly appreciate any thoughts on:

  • Why organization-level HRBP management is not considered best practice in SuccessFactors
  • Whether there are better workarounds for this requirement
